Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SHINE--Magnetic Energy Release During Solar Eruptions - From Large to Small Scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
This 3-year SHINE project is aimed at gaining a comprehensive understanding of the physical connection between small-scale physical processes at magnetic reconnection sites in the solar atmosphere and the evolution of solar eruptions at greater scales. This, the project has the potential to significantly advance knowledge of the energy release process in solar eruptions. In particular, the project will explore the relationship between small-scale energy release in the form of outflows in the current sheet region and the large-scale transport of thermal energy in the flare structure. The integrated modeling efforts will form the basis of the development of a more sophisticated, full three-dimensional (3-D) simulation of solar eruptions in the future.

The 3-year research program integrates two sets of well-developed, state-of-the-art magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) simulations: one simulation models the large-scale structure and evolution of solar flares, whereas the other simulation targets detailed dynamics in and around the reconnection current sheet region at small scales. The large-scale flare simulation will be used to set up the context and initial conditions for the detailed full 3-D simulation of the reconnection region. The outputs of the detailed small scale 3-D simulation, in turn, will provide feedback and update the large-scale simulation to evaluate the consequences of small-scale energy release processes. The modeling results will be compared with extreme ultraviolet (EUV) and X-ray observations to test and improve our understanding of the energy release and conversion processes from small to large scales. A variety of well observed, but poorly understood phenomena that are closely tied to the energy release processes will be investigated and compared to model outputs, including supra-arcade down-flows and other fast plasma outflows, current-sheet like structures above flare loops, and hot loop-top EUV/X-ray sources.

The improved knowledge on the origin of solar eruptions is critical to understand basic science needed to meet the goals of the National Space Weather Strategy and Action Plan, which aims to develop tools to forecast space weather and mitigate its impacts. The project team will involve students in this SHINE research through the established CfA's Solar Physics Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program. These students come from a wide variety of backgrounds, including traditionally underrepresented groups in the sciences. Thus, the research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project "Collaborative Research: SHINE--Magnetic Energy Release During Solar Eruptions - From Large to Small Scales" aimed to gain a comprehensive understanding of the connection between small-scale physical processes in the reconnection region and the evolution of solar eruptions at greater scales. To achieve the goal, we combined state-of-the-art magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) simulations and multi-wavelength observations of eruptive solar flares to test and improve our understanding of the flare energy release and conversion processes from small to large scales.

The combined modeling-observation approach has led to breakthrough results in deciphering the energy release processes of a large, textbook-like solar eruption event on 2017 September 10. Using microwave imaging spectroscopy observations from the NSF-funded Expanded Owens Valley Solar Array (EOVSA), we reported the microwave counterpart of the eruption (Chen et al. 2020, The Astrophysical Journal) and revealed a more complex picture of nonthermal emissions from flare-accelerated electrons than previously thought (Gary et al. 2018, The Astrophysical Journal). Moreover, these data allowed us to derive the magnetic field distribution in the reconnection current sheet region (known as solar flares "central engine") for the first time, which agreed very well with our global-scale MHD model predictions. We found that the energetic electrons were concentrated at the bottom of the current sheet at the looptops that constituted a "magnetic bottle" structure but not the reconnection site itself. These results have profound implications for understanding the catastrophic energy release and particle acceleration processes, which are outstanding topics in solar physics, space physics, and astrophysics. The results were published in Nature Astronomy (Chen et al. 2020) and received wide attention in the community (including a news story issued by NSF, and an article published in the Astronomy Magazine).

At smaller scales, our multi-wavelength observations resulted in an improved understanding of the plasma outflows in the flare current sheet in driving thermal and nonthermal emissions at the top of the flare arcades (known as the "looptop" region; Yu et al. 2020, The Astrophysical Journal), as well as long-period oscillations detected there using ultraviolet spectroscopy, possibly due to the "magnetic tuning fork" mechanism (Reeves et al. 2020, The Astrophysical Journal). Our detailed modeling and observations for the looptop region, where the reconnection outflows meet the flare arcade and produce a fast-mode "termination shock", yielded new measurements of the shock compression ratio and its spatiotemporal variation in response to the outflows (Chen et al. 2019, The Astrophysical Journal).

The project has provided partial funding support, training, and professional development to postdoctoral fellow Dr. Sijie Yu, who in August 2020 was promoted to Assistant Research Professor at the Center for Solar-Terrestrial Research of the New Jersey Institute of Technology. PI Chen and Dr. Yu published their results in peer-reviewed publications and disseminated them at several conferences and workshops. PI Chen also gave public lectures to local astronomy clubs in New Jersey and New York State on topics related to this project.
